description: From Middle English dissenten, from Latin dissentire (“to differ in sentiments, disagree, be at odds, contradict, quarrel”), from dis- + sentire (see sense).

entries.meaning: Disagreement with the ideas, doctrines, decrees, etc. of a political party, government or religion.
An act of disagreeing with, or deviating from, the views and opinions of those holding authority.
(Anglo-American common law) A separate opinion filed in a case by judges who disagree with the outcome of the majority of the court in that case
(sports) A violation that arises when disagreement with an official call is expressed in an inappropriate manner such as foul language, rude gestures, or failure to comply.
examples: City had been woeful, their anger at their own inertia summed up when Samir Nasri received a booking for dissent, and they did not have a shot on target until the 66th minute.

verbs.description: dissent (third-person singular simple present dissents, present participle dissenting, simple past and past participle dissented)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To disagree; to withhold assent. Construed with from (or, formerly, to).
examples: Where a trustee refuses either to assent or dissent, the Court will itself exercise his authority.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To differ from, especially in opinion, beliefs, etc.
examples: Some are so eristical and teasty, that they will not ... bear with any that dissent.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To be different; to have contrary characteristics.
